body:
Seeing the same thing.  It works in some cases but not for `xUnit`  for example.   I belive .netStandard is being public signed unintentionally.

Repro:
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>net472</TargetFramework>
    <ImplicitUsings>enable</ImplicitUsings>
    <Nullable>enable</Nullable>

    <IsPackable>false</IsPackable>
    <IsTestProject>true</IsTestProject>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="AutoMapper" Version="15.0.0" />
    <PackageReference Include="coverlet.collector" Version="6.0.0" />
    <PackageReference Include="Microsoft.NET.Test.Sdk" Version="17.8.0" />
    <PackageReference Include="xunit" Version="2.5.3" />
    <PackageReference Include="xunit.runner.visualstudio" Version="2.5.3" />
  </ItemGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <Using Include="Xunit" />
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```
```c#
    public class UnitTest1
    {
        [Fact]
        public void Test1()
        {
            try
            {
                var assembly = Assembly.Load("AutoMapper, Version=15.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=be96cd2c38ef1005");
            }
            catch (Exception ex)
            {
                throw;
            }
        }
    }
```

What works:
Reference the local build directly and replace:
```xml
<PackageReference Include="AutoMapper" Version="15.0.0" />
```
with 
```xml
    <Reference Include="AutoMapper">
      <HintPath>..\..\..\LuckyPennySoftware\AutoMapper\src\AutoMapper\bin\Debug\netstandard2.0\AutoMapper.dll</HintPath>
    </Reference>
```

To reproduce the error locally (on windows):  In AutoMapper.csproj replace:
```xml
<PublicSign Condition=" '$(OS)' != 'Windows_NT' ">true</PublicSign>
```
with
```xml
<PublicSign Condition=" '$(OS)' == 'Windows_NT' ">true</PublicSign>
```
rebuild and try again.
Ahhhh yes, the `netstandard2.0` version should not be public signed. Only `net8.0` etc. I'll get a fix out ASAP.
Actually, I don't think that PublicSign business is needed at all. Just going to remove it.

@BlaiseD I don't actually have a Windows machine so I couldn't reproduce this locally (it didn't fail in Parallels, no idea why). But the `sn.exe` tool showed that the strong name was not valid for the `netstandard2.0` version before I removed the public sign business.

I think this one came about because I switched some of the build images a while back to Ubuntu.

> [@BlaiseD](https://github.com/BlaiseD) I don't actually have a Windows machine so I couldn't reproduce this locally (it didn't fail in Parallels, no idea why). But the `sn.exe` tool showed that the strong name was not valid for the `netstandard2.0` version before I removed the public sign business.
> 
> I think this one came about because I switched some of the build images a while back to Ubuntu.

Makes sense.  I can confirm it is resolved now in v15.0.1.

issue.title: Argument types do not match
issue.body:
Since #4545 was closed and v15.0.1 was released I tried to give it a shot again. I believe the underlying issue was resolved because I was able to hit the sign in page and sign in on my project. However, I got the following exception there after.

> [!WARNING]
>
> Argument types do not match

My solution has hundreds of mappings, where each slice has it's own file-scoped mappings, so it is basically impossible for me to figure out which mappings are triggering the exception. Is there a way to be able to find out which mappings are the problem? Here's the stack trace too:

body: This issue has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
